awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Effects of Chemical Aging on the Ice Nucleation Properties of Natural and Anthropogenic Atmospheric Particles
awd_abstract_narration:
Through this CAREER award funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation, Professor Ryan Sullivan of Carnegie Mellon University is experimentally investigating the effects of atmospheric chemical processing on ice formation initiated (nucleated) by particles in the environment. While chemical reactions are known to alter the freezing properties of ice-nucleating particles, current representations of the process by which water droplets become ice particles in cloud and climate models are largely based on the properties of fresh (or unaged) particles. By determining the changes in the freezing properties of realistic particle systems, this research advances our understanding of how human activities affect cloud evolution and ice formation. The development of educational modules to be loaned to K-12 teachers expose young students to the chemical science and measurement of air pollution, acid rain, and cloud forming reactions. The creation of a series of new hands-on laboratory experiments for the core undergraduate instrumental analysis course at CMU enhances the training of college students in modern chemical analysis.

Mineral dust and volcanic ash particles, and biomass burning (wood smoke) aerosol, is chemically aged using a chamber or flow tube reactor to determine the effects of atmospheric processing by anthropogenic pollutants on the contact and immersion freezing properties of these important natural sources of ice-nucleating particles. The effects of chemical aging on particle composition, mixing state, and ice nucleation properties are determined using an extensive combination of online and offline single-particle characterization. This includes online analysis using two single-particle mass spectrometers, and offline spectromicroscopic analysis of particles and ice crystal residues. The contact freezing efficiency of these particle systems is directly measured using a chilled aerosol optical tweezers system. Immersion freezing temperature spectra of particles immersed in droplets is obtained using a droplet in oil cold plate system. This research produces a comprehensive dataset regarding the heterogeneous ice nucleation properties of important types of ice nucleating particles, and the effects of atmospheric processing on their freezing ability. The measurements is parameterized to produce improved representations of the chemical composition and related ice nucleation properties of biomass burning and mineral particles in cloud and atmospheric chemistry models.

por.por_cntn:
Ice nucleating particles catalyze the freezing of water at temperatures above the homogeneous freezing point of ca. –35 ºC for micron-sized droplets. This is an important but complex phase transition that continues to receive much study from both physical chemistry, and the atmospheric sciences due to the important implications of the resulting cloud glaciation on the microphysical properties of clouds, precipitation, weather, the hydrological cycle, and climate change. This project investigated the sources of ice nucleating particles and how they respond to chemical transformation in two types of understudied environmental particle matrices: biomass-burning aerosol emitted by wildfires and combustion, and volcanic ash.

Biomass-burning had previously been observed to sometimes produce ice nucleating particles though the source of these rare particles remained undetermined. We discovered that the primary source of ice nucleating particles emitted from biomass burning of tall grass fuels relevant to global biomass fuel types are new mineral phases produced by the biomass combustion process. This challenged the prevailing idea that graphitic soot was the main source of the ice nucleating particles and added further evidence against soot particles contributing to ice nucleation at immersion freezing temperatures above –35 ºC. The mineral-based ice nucleating particles were identified using X-ray diffraction analysis of the bottom ash produced by biomass combustion, and using electron microscopy with energy dispersive X-ray analysis of collected aerosol particles. Some of this analysis was performed at the Environmental Molecular Sciences Laboratory at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory. The microfluidic ice nucleation technique (MINT) developed in our lab was used to determine the immersion freezing temperature spectra of the ash and aerosol particle samples. The discovery of mineral particles as a major source of ice nucleating particles produced by biomass burning has important broader impacts regarding the many effects that wildfires impose on environmental systems, cloud microphysics, and climate. These findings will also change how these questions are addressed using large-scale atmospheric models, and our understanding of the molecular-level properties of complex particles introduced into the environment by biomass burning.

The ice nucleation ability of these biomass-burning particles was found to sometimes be enhanced through simulated atmospheric chemical aging of the smoke in a large chamber reactor. Several types of aging schemes were studied including oxidation by ozone in the dark, photochemical oxidation by hydroxyl radicals, and a “time aging” control where semi-volatile aerosol components evaporated over an hour of time suspended in the chamber. We determined that the removal of low-volatility (tar-like) organic carbon coatings emitted with the smoke aerosol through evaporation and/or oxidation that promotes dissolution explains the enhancement in ice nucleation activity. Chemical transformation pathways that promote the evaporation or dissolution of these primary organic carbon particle coatings expose the ice-active mineral surfaces also emitted by biomass burning, making these ice nucleating surfaces available to interact with water and catalyze freezing. These findings resolve long standing questions pertaining to the nature of heterogeneous ice nucleation in biomass-burning aerosol and ash, providing a clearer understanding of how these particles and their ice nucleation ability are altered at the molecular level during atmospheric transport and chemical aging.

The ice nucleation properties of complex authentic volcanic ash samples and their chemical properties and compositions were examined. We determined an unrecognized contribution to the immersion freezing properties from pyroxene minerals, in addition to the well-known ice-active feldspar minerals. Using various types of aqueous chemical aging with chemical analysis of the altered volcanic ash and the aqueous extract allowed us to identify four types of mineral transformation pathways with different effects on the ice nucleation ability. Knowledge from mineralogy, inorganic chemistry, and geology pertaining to the stability ordering of different mineral phases along with machine learning analysis of the ice nucleation and chemical measurements enabled the determination of the different mineral aging pathways that are controlled by the original mineral phases present and the type of aqueous chemical aging. Some of these experiments were conducted by an undergraduate student in chemistry during an international summer exchange at the University of Leeds. This student also developed new statistical approaches to the analysis of droplet freezing temperature spectra commonly used to assess ice nucleation properties, in collaboration with a professor of statistics.

Several hands-on activities were developed into deployable modules to advance educational outreach around chemistry and environmental science. We tested and refined these modules through partnership with the Sense of Place Learning afterschool program in local K-12 public schools in Pittsburgh with high levels of underrepresented students. The modules include acids and bases with application to acid rain, ice nucleation caused by mineral particles, and the use of microscopy to visualize complex environmental samples and chemical processes. Three chemistry PhD students conducted significant portions of their dissertation through this project, along with two undergraduate chemistry students who also completed an additional Master’s degree in chemistry with thesis.
